15.text: Fifteen years ago, it was widely assumed

18.text: that the vast majority of brain development

20.text: takes place in the first few years of life.

23.text: Back then, 15 years ago, we didn't have the ability

26.text: to look inside the living human brain

29.text: and track development across the lifespan.

32.text: In the past decade or so, mainly due to advances

37.text: such as magnetic resonance imaging, or MRI,

40.text: neuroscientists have started to look inside the living

43.text: human brain of all ages, and to track changes

45.text: in brain structure and brain function,

48.text: so we use structural MRI if you'd like to take a snapshot,

52.text: a photograph, at really high resolution of the inside

55.text: of the living human brain, and we can ask questions like,

58.text: how much gray matter does the brain contain,

60.text: and how does that change with age?

62.text: And we also use functional MRI, called fMRI,

66.text: to take a video, a movie, of brain activity

69.text: when participants are taking part in some kind of task

72.text: like thinking or feeling or perceiving something.

75.text: So many labs around the world are involved in this kind

78.text: of research, and we now have a really rich

80.text: and detailed picture of how the living human brain develops,

84.text: and this picture has radically changed the way

87.text: we think about human brain development

89.text: by revealing that it's not all over in early childhood,

92.text: and instead, the brain continues to develop

95.text: right throughout adolescence and into the '20s and '30s.

99.text: So adolescence is defined as the period of life that starts

103.text: with the biological, hormonal, physical changes of puberty

107.text: and ends at the age at which an individual attains

111.text: a stable, independent role in society.

116.text: It can go on a long time. (Laughter)

119.text: One of the brain regions that changes most dramatically

122.text: during adolescence is called prefrontal cortex.

125.text: So this is a model of the human brain,

128.text: and this is prefrontal cortex, right at the front.

131.text: Prefrontal cortex is an interesting brain area.

133.text: It's proportionally much bigger in humans than

136.text: in any other species, and it's involved in a whole range of

140.text: high level cognitive functions, things like decision-making,

143.text: planning, planning what you're going to do tomorrow

145.text: or next week or next year, inhibiting

148.text: inappropriate behavior, so stopping yourself saying

151.text: something really rude or doing something really stupid.

154.text: It's also involved in social interaction,

159.text: So MRI studies looking at the development of this region

162.text: have shown that it really undergoes dramatic development

167.text: So if you look at gray matter volume, for example,

170.text: gray matter volume across age from age four to 22 years

175.text: increases during childhood, which is what you can see

177.text: on this graph. It peaks in early adolescence.

181.text: The arrows indicate peak gray matter volume

183.text: in prefrontal cortex. You can see that that peak happens

187.text: a couple of years later in boys relative to girls,

190.text: and that's probably because boys go through puberty

192.text: a couple of years later than girls on average,

195.text: and then during adolescence, there's a significant decline

198.text: in gray matter volume in prefrontal cortex.

201.text: Now that might sound bad, but actually this is

203.text: a really important developmental process, because

206.text: gray matter contains cell bodies and connections

210.text: between cells, the synapses, and this decline

213.text: in gray matter volume during prefrontal cortex

216.text: is thought to correspond to synaptic pruning,

221.text: This is a really important process. It's partly dependent

224.text: on the environment that the animal or the human is in,

228.text: and the synapses that are being used are strengthened,

231.text: and synapses that aren't being used

233.text: in that particular environment are pruned away.

235.text: You can think of it a bit like pruning a rosebush.

238.text: You prune away the weaker branches so that

241.text: the remaining, important branches, can grow stronger,

244.text: and this process, which effectively fine-tunes brain tissue

250.text: is happening in prefrontal cortex and in other brain regions

253.text: during the period of human adolescence.

257.text: So a second line of inquiry that we use to track changes

260.text: in the adolescent brain is using functional MRI

264.text: to look at changes in brain activity across age.

267.text: So I'll just give you an example from my lab.

269.text: So in my lab, we're interested in the social brain, that is

272.text: the network of brain regions that we use to understand

276.text: other people and to interact with other people.

278.text: So I like to show a photograph of a soccer game

282.text: to illustrate two aspects of how your social brains work.

286.text: So this is a soccer game. (Laughter)

288.text: Michael Owen has just missed a goal, and he's lying

290.text: on the ground, and the first aspect of the social brain

293.text: that this picture really nicely illustrates is how automatic

296.text: and instinctive social emotional responses are,

299.text: so within a split second of Michael Owen missing this goal,

302.text: everyone is doing the same thing with their arms

304.text: and the same thing with their face, even Michael Owen

306.text: as he slides along the grass, is doing the same thing

308.text: with his arms, and presumably has a similar

310.text: facial expression, and the only people who don't

312.text: are the guys in yellow at the back — (Laughs) —

315.text: and I think they're on the wrong end of the stadium,

318.text: and they're doing another social emotional response

320.text: that we all instantly recognize, and that's the second aspect

323.text: of the social brain that this picture really nicely illustrates,

326.text: how good we are at reading other people's behavior,

330.text: their actions, their gestures, their facial expressions,

333.text: in terms of their underlying emotions and mental states.

336.text: So you don't have to ask any of these guys.

338.text: You have a pretty good idea of what they're feeling

341.text: and thinking at this precise moment in time.

343.text: So that's what we're interested in looking at in my lab.

345.text: So in my lab, we bring adolescents and adults into the lab

349.text: to have a brain scan, we give them some kind of task

351.text: that involves thinking about other people, their minds,

354.text: their mental states, their emotions, and one of the findings

357.text: that we've found several times now, as have other labs

360.text: around the world, is part of the prefrontal cortex called

363.text: medial prefrontal cortex, which is shown in blue on the slide,

366.text: and it's right in the middle of prefrontal cortex

369.text: in the midline of your head.

372.text: This region is more active in adolescents when they make

375.text: these social decisions and think about other people

377.text: than it is in adults, and this is actually a meta-analysis

380.text: of nine different studies in this area from labs around

383.text: the world, and they all show the same thing, that activity

386.text: in this medial prefrontal cortex area decreases

392.text: And we think that might be because adolescents and adults

394.text: use a different mental approach, a different

397.text: cognitive strategy, to make social decisions,

404.text: whereby we bring people into the lab and we give them

405.text: some kind of behavioral task, and I'll just give you

408.text: another example of the kind of task that we use in my lab.

481.text: normal, healthy, intelligent adults like you make errors

484.text: about 50 percent of the time on that kind of trial.

487.text: They move the white truck instead of the blue truck.

490.text: So we give this kind of task to adolescents and adults,

493.text: and we also have a control condition

495.text: where there's no director and instead we give people a rule.

499.text: We tell them, okay, we're going to do exactly the same thing

501.text: but this time there's no director. Instead you've got to

509.text: in the no-director condition they just have to remember

512.text: to apply this somewhat arbitrary rule, whereas

515.text: in the director condition, they have to remember

517.text: to take into account the director's perspective

520.text: in order to guide their ongoing behavior.

593.text: else's perspective in order to guide ongoing behavior,

603.text: So if you have a teenage son or a daughter and you

611.text: So we sometimes laugh about teenagers.

615.text: They're parodied, sometimes even demonized in the media

619.text: for their kind of typical teenage behavior. They take risks,

622.text: they're sometimes moody, they're very self-conscious.

625.text: I have a really nice anecdote from a friend of mine

628.text: who said that the thing he noticed most

630.text: about his teenage daughters before and after puberty

633.text: was their level of embarrassment in front of him.

635.text: So, he said, "Before puberty, if my two daughters

638.text: were messing around in a shop, I'd say, 'Hey,

640.text: stop messing around and I'll sing your favorite song,'

642.text: and instantly they'd stop messing around and he'd sing

644.text: their favorite song. After puberty, that became the threat.

649.text: The very notion of their dad singing in public

653.text: was enough to make them behave.

710.text: their behavior in terms of the underlying changes

713.text: that are going on in their brain.

715.text: So for example, take risk-taking. We know that adolescents

719.text: have a tendency to take risks. They do.

721.text: They take more risks than children or adults,

724.text: and they are particularly prone to taking risks

726.text: when they're with their friends. There's an important drive

729.text: to become independent from one's parents

732.text: and to impress one's friends in adolescence.

734.text: But now we try to understand that in terms of

737.text: the development of a part of their brain called the limbic system,

740.text: so I'm going to show you the limbic system in red

742.text: in the slide behind me, and also on this brain.

744.text: So the limbic system is right deep inside the brain,

747.text: and it's involved in things like emotion processing

751.text: and reward processing. It gives you the rewarding feeling

754.text: out of doing fun things, including taking risks.

758.text: It gives you the kick out of taking risks.

760.text: And this region, the regions within the limbic system,

763.text: have been found to be hypersensitive to the rewarding

766.text: feeling of risk-taking in adolescents compared with adults,

770.text: and at the very same time, the prefrontal cortex,

774.text: which you can see in blue in the slide here,

776.text: which stops us taking excessive risks,

779.text: is still very much in development in adolescents.
